content:
The "Nuclear Regulatory Commission Authorization Act for Fiscal Years 1994 and 1995" includes authorization of appropriations for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, allocation of funds, retention of funds, transfer of certain funds, and limitations. Additionally, it addresses nuclear power plant safety and security. Sec. 201-208 outline various regulations and penalties related to nuclear safety and security. Sec. 101 authorizes appropriations for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for fiscal years 1994 and 1995. Authorized appropriations for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for fiscal years 1994 and 1995 include $530,200,000 and $541,417,000 respectively, with $22,000,000 from the Nuclear Waste Fund. Additionally, funds are authorized for the Office of the Inspector General. The Office of the Inspector General of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is appropriated $4,800,000 for fiscal year 1994 and $5,000,000 for fiscal year 1995, to remain available until expended. SEC. 102. ALLOCATION OF AMOUNTS AUTHORIZED. The amounts authorized for fiscal years 1994 and 1995 are allocated as follows: $161,002,000 for reactor safety and safeguards regulation in 1994, $166,215,000 in 1995; $92,795,000 for reactor safety research in 1994, $89,318,000 in 1995; $30,731,000 for reactor special and independent reviews, investigations, and enforcement in 1994, $31,674,000 in 1995. For fiscal years 1994 and 1995, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission allocated specific amounts for nuclear material and low-level waste safety and safeguards regulation, high-level nuclear waste regulation, and nuclear safety management and support. The allocated funds for each category are outlined for each fiscal year. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission may use up to 1 percent of allocated funds to make grants and agreements with organizations. Funds can be reallocated for different programs as needed. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission can reallocate funds for programs up to $500,000 without exceeding the limit until notifying the relevant committees. Amounts from the Nuclear Waste Fund can only be used for high-level nuclear waste activities of the Commission and cannot be reallocated for other Commission activities. SEC. 103. RETENTION OF FUNDS.

Amounts received by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for cooperative nuclear safety research, services to foreign governments, and material access programs can be retained for salaries and expenses, subject to appropriations, and remain available until expended.

SEC. 104. TRANSFER OF CERTAIN FUNDS. SEC. 104. TRANSFER OF CERTAIN FUNDS.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission can transfer funds to its Inspector General from appropriations, not exceeding 5 percent of the authorized amount for the fiscal year. 

SEC. 105. LIMITATION.

No payments can be made under this title without prior approval in appropriation Acts.

TITLE II--NUCLEAR POWER PLANT SAFETY AND SECURITY

SEC. 201. NOTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS.

Amends the Energy Reorganization Act of 1974 regarding notification requirements. The curr_chunk discusses "noncompliance" without providing specific details. A person involved in a facility regulated by the Atomic Energy Act must notify the Commission immediately if they discover a defect or noncompliance that poses a safety hazard. The Commission may issue regulations and orders to ensure compliance with notification requirements for defects or failures in facilities regulated by the Atomic Energy Act. Failure to notify or comply with regulations may result in civil penalties. The Atomic Energy Act allows for civil penalties for failure to provide notice of defects or non-compliance. Individuals must have knowledge of the notification requirement and the defect to be penalized. Businesses must prominently display the notification requirements on their premises. The Commission may conduct inspections and enforcement activities to ensure compliance with regulations. The term 'person' includes the Department of Energy in certain cases. The term 'person' in regulations does not include individuals unless they are sole proprietors, partners, or directors of businesses related to specified components. This section applies to the United States Enrichment Corporation and its facilities, as well as its directors and officers. The section applies to the United States Enrichment Corporation, its facilities, directors, and officers, as well as any other person subject to this section. Civil monetary penalties may be imposed for violations of rules, regulations, orders, or licensing requirements. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include civil penalties for violations of licensing provisions, certification provisions, terms, conditions, or limitations of a license or certification, and rules, regulations, or orders issued under the provisions. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include civil penalties of up to $100,000 for violations of licensing provisions, certification provisions, and rules issued under the Act. Continuing violations result in separate daily penalties, and the Commission has the authority to adjust the penalties as needed. Section 234 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include notification by the Commission and action by the Attorney General. The table of contents is updated accordingly. SEC. 234. Civil monetary penalties for violations of rules, regulations, orders, or licensing requirements. SEC. 203. Report of advisory committee on reactor safeguards amended to biennial reporting. SEC. 204. Carrying of firearms by licensee employees. Section 161 k. of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include licensees and employees of contractors of licensees, expand the scope of facilities covered, and include licensees of the Commission in certain provisions. SEC. 205 amends the Atomic Energy Act to include facilities for nuclear fuel storage under licensing authority. SEC. 206 addresses sabotage of construction sites for nuclear facilities. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include provisions for intentional destruction or damage to nuclear facilities, waste storage facilities, or construction sites that could impact public health and safety. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include penalties for intentional destruction or damage to nuclear facilities, waste storage facilities, or construction sites, with fines up to $10,000 or imprisonment up to 10 years, or both. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to address interruptions of normal operation. SEC. 207 introduces civil penalties of $20,000 for violations of medical therapy licenses. SEC. 208 mandates the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to enhance education and training requirements for individuals licensed to handle nuclear byproduct materials for medical purposes within a year of the Act's enactment.
